Adam, please read more closely. This is the second time that you have distorted what we have written.

Your idea is not unwelcome. I have stated -- a few times -- that what you propose (the ability to manage dependencies of the sort you describe) is a good idea and would likely be welcome to others. All I have said is that I do not believe it belongs at the core of JUnit.

As for hoping that the JUnit team will assist you, I guess you don't know the JUnit team very well. Kent and Erich are nice folks, but they are not active contributors to JUnit these days. Just look at the gulfs in time between releases to convince yourself. Kent and Erich are not going to jump on board and help you with this. They don't have the time or energy. The real activity is in add-on projects like JUnit-addons.

JUnit is an excellent example of a well-closed package -- not perfect, but pretty damn good -- so that the vast majority of new features can be implemented easily enough by adding onto JUnit rather than changing its core. I think this is a testament to JUnit's design. The majority of extensions/changes fall into three categories:

* Customized assertions
* Custom Test Runners
* Custom classes to sit at the root of a TestCase hierarchy

HTMLUnit is an example of the first. Artima's suite runner is an example of the second. StrutsTestCase is an example of the third.

A good solution to your problem is the second: a custom test runner with a dependency graph collector/analyzer.

> > Also, much as I could craft some sort of add on

You conclude that the community of developers is not open to accepting a core change.

The alternate conclusion is that the community of developers does not believe your particular proposed change is a good idea.

On what basis did you choose your conclusion over the alternative?

When you are ready to accept the possibility that we merely disagree with you, rather than are nefariously blocking your proposal, please come back and discuss this with us again.

(Incidentally, I don't see how we can block your proposal, anyway. We don't own JUnit.)
